module.p: litir letter is a feminine simple common noun.

section.p:
The principal parts of litir are –
litir – nominative/dative singular
litreach – genitive singular
litrichean – plural

section.p:
Examples with the definite article as pre-specifier –
older pedagogical examples –
Tha mo mhàthair a’ sgrìobhadh litreach gu m’athair a tha air falbh. Thubhairt mo mhàthair, “An téid thu do bhocsa nan litrichean leis an litir seo, Iain?” “Théid,” ars Iain, “falbhaidh mi an dràsda”. “Fuirich gus an dùin mi i is gus an cuir mi seòladh oirre. Ceannaich fhéin stamp agus cuir oirre i.” Tha Iain a’ ruith sìos an rathad leis an litir ’na làimh. Théid e a steach do oifig a’ phuist, ceannaichidh e stamp is cuiridh e sud air an litir. Tilgidh e an litir ann am bocsa nan litrichean.
My mother is writing a letter to my father who is away. My mother said, “Will you go to the postbox with this letter, John?” “Yes, I will,” said John, “I will leave now.” “Wait until I seal it and put an address on it. Buy a stamp and put it on it.” John is running down the road with the letter in his hand. He will go into the post office, he will buy a stamp and put that on the letter. He will toss the letter into the postbox. td. 5

The intended recipient can be introduced by the preposition gu to –
pedagogical examples –
Sgrìobh e litir ghoirid gu caraid dha.
He wrote a short letter to a friend of his. td. 346
older pedagogical examples –
Tha mo mhàthair a’ sgrìobhadh litreach gu m’athair a tha air falbh.
My mother is writing a letter to my father who is away. td. 5

litir can be used as the complement of a preposition –
air litir on a letter –
cuir air litir put something on a letter –
cuir seòladh air litir address a letter
cuir stampa air litir put a stamp on a letter
le litir with a letter –
